I agree.  

I made my first account a long time ago when I learned about the game from the Golden Joystick awards.  League of Legends was competing for the award against the game I played most back then, Runescape.  

Now, many former Runescape players are all too familiar with what happened to that game.  There were many contributing factors to its fall, but a very major one, and perhaps the real beginning of the end, was their movement to micro-transactions and pay-to-win features.  Jagex, the company who owns and runs Runescape, had long taken a moral stance against pay-to-win in ways such as strict punishment of players trading real money for in-game items from other players.  They had also made an effort to prevent player-run gambling in the game.  

Then after all this and more, Jagex had some changes of management and someone signed off on the creation of what is essentially a huge and obnoxious roulette wheel built into the game where you can gamble real money to win in-game items, gold, and advantages.  They quickly made a lot of horrible decisions that further degraded the game into a quick facebook-esque cash grab, complete with constant popup reminders to spend money... 

I always figured League of Legends would die in the same way, especially when Tencent started investing since they bought out Jagex shortly before Runescape was sucked dry.  However, Riot seems to be avoiding the same pitfalls that destroyed Jagex.  I think it's because Riot is still controlled by the original creators who actually care about their legacy and fans more than the money.  Jagex was a much different company when it was run by its founders, the Gower brothers, but the original owner was eventually driven out, stating that he felt he had lost control of the company to internal politics (business management was handled by a hired CEO).  I think if Tryndamere or the other founders leave, then their replacements might destroy League of Legends out of greed too.

I also agree that the Hextech Crafting was surprisingly generous to us players in the way it has been implemented.  I was paranoid that it was Riot feeling the waters for some new aggressive marketing gimmick, but it seems I was mostly mistaken.  It is skewed towards requiring players to pay for keys, but there are no high-pressure tactics involved that would outweigh the original generosity of the free skins.  In the end, I feel grateful of Riot regardless of whether I decide to spend money or not.  I am glad that they haven't turned to blatant manipulation to "squeeze" players for money, or annoying popup sale ads, or pay-to-win features.  I think that Riot will keep going strong if the current management maintains control and they keep their passion for the game without getting greedy.  I am usually somewhat cynical, but I have honestly been pleasantly surprised by Riot for the most part, and I think they really have pretty creative, benevolent, capable, and intelligent people in charge.

Riot does a lot of good but they also do a lot of bad. All this said...

* Riot's skin model is pretty much the standard across the industry.
* League's basis served as the status quo to either meet or surpass.
* Around a 2 week balancing period (I actually can't think of any game like this) means that by the time a patch has shipped, they're already getting data.
* Riot's communication, while full of hiccups, is pretty damn amazing.

But for bad? They're slow in other categories. They can be headscratching with their desire for data and overall they're problematic in any number of categories such as esports rulings.
Riot's a company with a lot of flaws and a lot of good. Just remember that they're a company, not your friend or your enemy.

Some guy asked me "isn't the balance in league shit"(IRL) and I didn't really know what to say. For LCS it's not that great at the best of times and abysmal most of the time but for the normal players it's rarely unbearable. 

You look at another MOBA like Dota2 and the balancing for the average player sucks ass. Certain heroes have 60% winrates and 40% playrates, while others are stuck at 35% winrates and .1% playrates. That doesn't seem super fun IMO.

The issue with league is that 10 champs at a time run away with the game, but in Dota, half of the heros in the game are just as overpowered as each other, so you still have choices. In League, Lucian and Xayah are pick/ban, and so are Fizz, Darius, etc. So there are more OP bullshit champs than we can ban, and if only one gets through, the other team is screwed. In Dota, you just fight fire with fire and it ends up working out. Kinda like if half the roster is Lee, and the other half is Urgot. Urgot is still playable, but only by people who know him. Meanwhile, everyone and their brother plays Lee, and do well anyway.

From a DotA2 player: it's not as bad as it sounds. The game is balanced for high level play for the most part, and this means that you "grow into" the balance and skill necessary to play the game, it isn't ever made to accommodate you and that can feel very rewarding. A lot of people can also play those 40% winrate heroes and do just fine even in pugs (I myself have a good record on Enchantress and she's one of my favorite heroes to play, for example). The thing is that a lot of those lower winrate champions have specific win conditions and that can require good teamwork and communication, like Chen, Io, and Enchantress. Some of them are down there because they could be flat-out abusive at high-level play and are hard to play well in the first place, like Arc Warden and Visage so any notable negative change affects pub play immensely. 

It's fun if you want a more mechanically intensive and complex game as a whole, but it's not for everyone nor should anyone claim it is. Just like Heroes of the Storm isn't for everybody, nor is League for everybody.
That's the one part I shortened to a footnote. IMO dota2's balancing sucks ass, but to others it's what game balancing should be like. Different games attract different people

Is what it is :) I personally don't like League's balance, but I have my own games to play for that kind of thing. I tend to comment more on the design than the balance itself as a result, when I can help it. League is a fun game
